banner.title: TP WorkLife 10/12
banner.mainContentHeadline: The podcast where science meets business
banner.mainContent: From fixing meetings to finding a mentor, get new insights to help you enjoy your time at work and thrive in your career.

videoData.title: A mathematical model for predicting Parkinson's
videoData.socialTitle: A mathematical model for predicting Parkinson's

nodes.whoTheyAre: Eleftheria Pissadaiki, PhD, has a long-term interest in brain diseases, neurodegeneration and particularly in the etiopathology of Parkinson’s disease. In joining the high impact research and human studies team at IBM, Eleftheria contributes her neuroscientist research on projects related to human care, Parkinson’s disease and the detection of motor signatures that foreshadow daily fluctuations of the disease’s symptoms.

videoData.description: What if we looked at Parkinson's as an neurological electrical problem? Brain researcher Eleftheria Pissadaki and her team study dopamine neurons, the neurons that selectively die during Parkinson's. They discovered that the bigger a neuron is, the more vulnerable it becomes because it simply requires more energy. This new insight is reframing the disease -- and by "finding the fuse box for each neuron" and figuring out how much energy it needs, may help us neuroprotect our brain cells.
videoData.socialDescription: What if we looked at Parkinson's as an neurological electrical problem?
